author: Catherine Romano
title: The Dining Room Setup That Keeps Conversation Flowing
text: YOU DON’T want people to walk into a room and think they know what it’s going to look like,” said interior designer Ray Booth, whose new book, “Evocative Interiors” (Rizzoli), features two examples of the unexpected: curving banquettes that hug dining tables in a way that elevates classic diner décor. He said the setup “allows for a bit of discovery.” One of his clients likes the demi-lune settee from Coup D’Etat he installed in her Southampton, N.Y., dining room (above) for its social lubrication, the way it pivots people slightly toward each other. “For dinner parties,” she said, “we seat people who don’t know each...
